concern:
This is in th USA. I am a mid career professional who has enrolled back in university to learn a new language. In the past year and a half, I have progressed to 4th year level classes. I dont intend to get a degree, and if I do, it has nothing to do with my carrer, which I will not be changing. I am doing this purely because I want to learn this language and become fluent. 

However this upcoming term, I have to travel for personal reasons and I wont be able to finish the term.  I already know this. But I also dont want to take such a long break from the language, for fear for losing it. The winter break was already over a month long. Also, this is an expensive endeavor since my status doesnt qualify me for any financial aid and I am paying for it all out of pocket. So I'd hate to pay for the whole term and only be able to attend a third.

I'd like to talk to the professor and ask if I can just sit in on her class, without officially being on the roster, and attending as long as possible. How terrible an idea is this?

FWIW, I did take a 3rd year class with this prof, so she knows me. But its hard to say how well she remembers me.

dialogue_total.statement: Hi there! How are you doing today? Is there anything on your mind that you'd like to talk about? I'm all ears!
I'm feeling a bit anxious about my ongoing studies right now. Yes, I'd like to discuss some uncertainties I'm facing with my course commitments.
Oh, I see! Uncertainty about studies can definitely cause anxiety. Can you tell me more about what's making you uncertain? Maybe we can work through some of these worries together.
I'm uncertain about handling potential interruptions in my studies, which is adding to my anxiety. I want to explore ways to maintain my learning momentum without disrupting my overall progress.

It sounds like you're facing some challenges with maintaining your learning momentum due to potential interruptions. It's great that you're thinking about ways to keep your progress steady. Have you considered any strategies that might help you stay on track even when unexpected disruptions come up?

I've considered discussing informal options with my professor to keep my studies ongoing despite interruptions. This approach could help me sustain my learning momentum and reduce my anxiety about breaks.

That's a proactive approach! To make your discussion with your professor more productive, would you prefer preparing a list of possible informal learning options or drafting an email to initiate the conversation first?

I think drafting an email to initiate the conversation would be more efficient for me, as it allows me to clearly outline my concerns upfront. This approach could help me maintain my learning momentum by facilitating a timely discussion with the professor.

It's great to see that you've identified some potential solutions to address your concerns. Drafting an email to initiate a conversation with your professor is a proactive step towards maintaining your learning momentum. I encourage you to follow through with this plan, and I wish you the best of luck in your studies. Please don't hesitate to reach out if you need further support in the future.
I'll go ahead and draft that email to my professor to keep my language learning on track during my travel. Thanks for helping me sort through this.
